{{original research|date=October 2018}} An '''Alcalde-Presidente''' is an [[Alcalde]] ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for municipal Mayor) who also functions as President(e) of a higher administrative level.
Cases include: *colonial [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]] on [[Puerto Rico]], 1879–1902; the last one succeeded himself as first 'normal' Alcalde *in [[Spain]]: **[[Mayor-President of Ceuta]], the head of government of [[Ceuta]], an autonomous city **[[Mayor-President of Melilla]], the head of government of [[Melilla]], autonomous city *As [[Singapore]] is a [[city-state]], its [[President of Singapore|President]] can be thought of a Mayor who also functions as a President of a higher (in this case, the highest) administrative level; however, the President of Singapore, though not entirely ceremonial, is [[Powers of the President of Singapore|not the city-state's chief executive]]. The [[Prime Minister of Singapore|Prime Minister]] does.
==Sources== *[http://www.worldstatesmen.org/US_Mayors2.html WorldStatesmen- here US Cities]

{{refimprove|date=November 2015}} An '''anti-keylogger''' (or '''anti–keystroke logger''') is a type of software specifically designed for the detection of [[keystroke logger]] software; often, such software will also incorporate the ability to delete or at least immobilize hidden keystroke logger software on a computer. In comparison to most [[anti-virus]] or [[anti-spyware]] software, the primary difference is that an anti-keylogger does not make a distinction between a ''legitimate'' keystroke-logging program and an ''illegitimate'' keystroke-logging program (such as malware); all keystroke-logging programs are flagged and optionally removed, whether they appear to be legitimate keystroke-logging software or not.
==Use of anti-keyloggers==
Keyloggers are sometimes part of malware packages downloaded onto computers without the owners' knowledge. Detecting the presence of a keylogger on a computer can be difficult. So-called anti- keylogging programs have been developed to thwart keylogging systems, and these are often effective when used properly.
Anti-keyloggers are used both by large organizations as well as individuals in order to scan for and remove (or in some cases simply immobilize) [[keystroke logging]] software on a computer. It is generally advised the software developers that anti-keylogging scans be run on a regular basis in order to reduce the amount of time during which a keylogger may record keystrokes. For example, if a system is scanned once every three days, there is a maximum of only three days during which a keylogger could be hidden on the system and recording keystrokes.
===Public computers===
[[Public computer]]s are extremely susceptible to the installation of [[keystroke logging]] software and hardware, and there are documented instances of this occurring.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scmagazineuk.com/keyloggers-found-plugged-into-library-computers/article/196936/ |title=Keyloggers found plugged into library computers |accessdate=25 April 2011|newspaper=SC Magazine}}</ref> Public computers are particularly susceptible to keyloggers because any number of people can gain access to the machine and install both a [[hardware keylogger]] and a software keylogger, either or both of which can be secretly installed in a matter of minutes.<ref name="SpyReveal Anti Keylogger">{{cite web|url=http://spyreveal.com/anti-keylogging-public-computers|work=Anti Keylogging & Public Computers|accessdate=10 May 2011|title=Anti Keylogging & Public Computers| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110522031359/http://spyreveal.com/anti-keylogging-public-computers| archivedate= 22 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Anti-keyloggers are often used on a daily basis to ensure that public computers are not infected with keyloggers, and are safe for public use.
===Gaming usage===
Keyloggers have been prevalent in the online gaming industry, being used to secretly record a gamer's access credentials, user name and password, when logging into an account, this information is sent back to the hacker. The hacker can sign on later to the account and change the password to the account, thus stealing it.
[[World of Warcraft]] has been of particular importance to game hackers and has been the target of numerous keylogging viruses. Anti-keyloggers are used by many World of Warcraft and other gaming community members in order to try to keep their gaming accounts secure.
===Financial institutions===
[[Financial institution]]s have become the target of keyloggers,<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber threat landscape faced by financial and insurance industry|url=http://www.aic.gov.au/publications/current%20series/tandi/401-420/tandi408.html|publisher=Dr Kim-Kwang Raymond Choo|accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref> particularly those institutions which do not use advanced security features such as [[Personal identification number|PIN]] pads or screen keyboards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/123397/article.html|work=Privacy Watch: More Criminals Use Keystroke Loggers|publisher=PC World About|title=Privacy Watch: More Criminals Use Keystroke Loggers}}</ref> Anti-keyloggers are used to run regular scans of any computer on which banking or client information is accessed, protecting passwords, banking information, and credit card numbers from identity thieves.
===Personal use===
The most common use of an anti-keylogger is by individuals wishing to protect their privacy while using their computer; uses range from protecting financial information used in online banking, any passwords, personal communication, and virtually any other information which may be typed into a computer. Keyloggers are often installed by people known by the computer's owner, and many times have been installed by an ex-partner hoping to spy on their ex-partner's activities, particularly chat.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/columnist/kimkomando/2010-03-04-computer-spying_N.htm|accessdate=25 April 2011|newspaper=USA Today | title=Is someone you know spying on you?|date=4 March 2010}}</ref>
== Types ==
===Signature-based=== This type of software has a signature base, that is strategic information that helps to uniquely identify a keylogger, and the list contains as many known keyloggers as possible. Some vendors make some effort or availability of an up-to-date listing for download by customers. Each time a 'System Scan' is run, this software compares the contents of the hard disk drive, item by item, against the list, looking for any matches.
This type of software is a rather widespread one, but it has its own drawbacks The biggest drawback of signature-based anti-keyloggers is that one can only be protected from keyloggers found on the signature-base list, thus staying vulnerable to unknown or unrecognized keyloggers. A criminal can download one of many famous keyloggers, change it just enough, and the anti-keylogger won't recognize it.
===Heuristic analysis=== This software doesn't use signature bases, it uses a checklist of known features, attributes, and methods that keyloggers are known use.
It analyzes the methods of work of all the modules in a PC, thus blocking the activity of any module that is similar to the work of keyloggers. Though this method gives better keylogging protection than signature-based anti-keyloggers, it has its own drawbacks. One of them is that this type of software blocks non-keyloggers also. Several 'non-harmful' software modules, either part of the operating system or part of legitimate apps, use processes which keyloggers also use, which can trigger a [[false positive]]. Usually all the non signature-based keyloggers have the option to allow the user to unblock selected modules, but this can cause difficulties for inexperienced users who are unable to discern good modules from bad modules when manually choosing to block or unblock.
==See also== * [[Keystroke logger]] * [[Hardware keylogger]]

{{redirect|Argentina default|previous Argentina sovereign debt defaults|Economic history of Argentina}} [[File:Prat gay en Washington.jpg|thumb|Minister [[Alfonso Prat Gay]] takes part in meetings with the IMF and the World Bank, shortly after the end of the default.]] The '''Argentine debt restructuring''' is a process of [[debt restructuring]] by [[Argentina]] that began on January 14, 2005, and allowed it to resume payment on 76% of the [[United States dollar|US$]]82 billion in [[sovereign bond]]s that defaulted in 2001 at the depth of [[Argentine economic crisis (1999–2002)|the worst economic crisis]] in the nation's history. A second debt restructuring in 2010 brought the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, though ongoing disputes with [[holdout problem|holdouts]] remained.<ref name=jf>{{cite web |url= https://fas.org/sgp/crs/row/R41029.pdf |title=Argentina's Defaulted Sovereign Debt: Dealing with the "Holdouts"|author=J.F.Hornbeck|work=[[Congressional Research Service]] |date=February 6, 2013}}</ref><ref name=nyt>{{cite web|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/02/25/banks-fear-court-ruling-in-argentina-bond-debt/?_r=0|title=Banks Fear Court Ruling in Argentina Bond Debt|work=The New York Times|date=February 25, 2013}}</ref> Bondholders who participated in the restructuring settled for repayments of around 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and began to be paid punctually; the value of their nearly worthless bonds also began to rise.<ref name=snub>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpolicy.org/social-and-economic-policy/the-world-economic-crisis/general-analysis-2/51203-billionaire-hedge-funds-snub-90-returns.html|title=Billionaire Hedge Funds Snub 90% Returns|author=Drew Benson|work=Bloomberg News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304795804579101591978033018|title=Argentina Bonds Rally Despite Risk|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=September 29, 2013}}</ref><ref name=ips>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2013/08/argentina-seeks-to-restructure-debt-held-by-vulture-funds/|title=Argentina Seeks to Restructure Debt Held by Vulture Funds|work=IPS News|date=August 29, 2013}}</ref> The remaining 7% of bondholders later won the right to be repaid in full.<ref name="Benson"/>
As part of the restructuring process, Argentina drafted agreements in which repayments would be handled through a [[New York (state)|New York]] corporation and governed by United States law. The holdout bondholders found themselves unable to seize Argentine sovereign assets in settlement,<ref name=forbes/> but realized that Argentina had omitted to provide for holdout situations and had instead deemed all bonds repayable on ''[[pari passu]]'' (equal) terms that prevented preferential treatment among bondholders. The holdout bondholders therefore sought, and won, an [[injunction]] in 2012 that prohibited Argentina from repaying the 93% of bonds that had been renegotiated, unless they simultaneously paid the 7% holdouts their full amount due as well. Together with the agreement's [[rights upon future offers]] ("RUFO") clause, this created a deadlock in which the 93% of renegotiated bondholders could not be paid without paying the 7% holdouts, but any payment to the holdouts would potentially (according to Argentina) trigger the 93% being due repayment at full value too; a sum of around $100 billion that Argentina could not afford.<ref name="telegraph31july2014">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/11004486/Argentina-accuses-US-of-judicial-malpractice-for-triggering-needless-default.html Argentina accuses US of judicial malpractice for triggering needless default], ''The Telegraph'', 31 July 2014.</ref> The courts ruled that as Argentina had itself drafted the agreement, and chosen the terms it wished to propose, it could not now claim the terms were unreasonable or unfair, and that this could not be worked around by asserting sovereign status since the injunction did not affect sovereign assets, but simply ruled that Argentina must not give preferential treatment of any group of bondholders over any other group when making repayments.
Subsequently, though Argentina wanted to repay some creditors, the judgment prevented Argentina from doing so, because being forced to repay all creditors, including the holdouts, would have totaled around $100 billion. The country was therefore categorized as being in [[Default (finance)|selective default]] by [[Standard & Poor's]] and in restricted default by [[Fitch Ratings|Fitch]].<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=4 September 2014|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2014/08/03/everything-you-need-to-know-about-argentinas-weird-default/|title=Everything you need to know about Argentina's weird default|work=Washington Post|date=3 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=selective>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/argentina-ruled-selective-default-bonds-p-203657630.html|title=Argentina blames US for debt woes, denies default|author=Paula Bustamante|agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|work=Yahoo! News|date=31 July 2014|accessdate=4 September 2014}}</ref> The ruling affected New York law Argentine bonds; Argentine bonds issued under Buenos Aires and [[European law]] were not affected.<ref name=muddled>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/25/business/rulings-add-to-the-mess-in-argentine-bonds.html?_r=1|title=The Muddled Case of Argentine Bonds|work=The New York Times|date=24 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=Europe>{{cite news|url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/166107/new-york-judge-allows-payment--to-bondholders-based-in-europe-|title=New York judge allows payment to bondholders in Europe|work=Buenos Aires Herald|date=2 August 2014|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
Proposed solutions include seeking [[waiver]]s of the RUFO clause from bondholders, or waiting for the RUFO clause to expire at the end of 2014.<ref name="telegraph31july2014"/> The dilemma raised concerns internationally about the ability of a small minority to forestall an otherwise-agreed debt restructuring of an insolvent country,<ref name="telegraph31july2014"/> and the ruling that led to it was widely criticized both within the United States and internationally. Although the media widely reported that the default ended with payments to the principal bondholders in early 2016, during the [[#Presidency of Mauricio Macri|presidency of Mauricio Macri]], several hundred million dollars in outstanding defaulted bonds remained unpaid, which resulted in continuation of litigation. In November 2016 Argentina announced that it had settled with additional creditors for US$475 million.<ref name="lanacion.com.ar">http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1957560-el-gobierno-pago-us-475-millones-a-los-tenedores-de-titulos-en-default</ref>
==Overview==
===Argentine financial crisis=== {{see also|1998–2002 Argentine great depression}} Around [[1998–2002 Argentine great depression|1998 to 2002, Argentina's economy]] went into severe [[recession]]. On December 26, 2001, Argentina defaulted on a total of [[United States dollar|US$]]93 billion of its [[external debt]]; of around $81.8 billion in bonds that were [[Default (finance)|default]]ed, 51% were issued during this three-year period.<ref name=info>{{cite news|url=http://www.infonews.com/2013/08/28/economia-94629-el-detalle-del-proyecto-para-el-nuevo-canje-de-deuda-reapertura-del-canje.php|title=El detalle del proyecto para el nuevo canje de deuda|work=InfoNews|date=August 28, 2013}}</ref> Foreign investment [[capital flight|fled the country]], and capital flow toward Argentina ceased almost completely from 2001 to 2003 (though it later recovered).<ref>{{cite web|title=Desde el 2003 aumentó la inversión extranjera productive |url=http://images.slideplayer.es/1/18037/slides/slide_7.jpg|work=MRECIC|date=June 2012}}</ref> The currency [[exchange rate]] (formerly a fixed 1-to-1 [[fixed exchange rate|parity]] between the [[Argentine peso]] and the [[United States dollar|U.S. dollar]]) was [[floating exchange rate|floated]], and the peso [[devaluation|devalued]] quickly to nearly 4-to-1, producing a sudden rise in [[inflation]] to over 40% and a fall in real GDP of 11% in 2002.<ref name=jf/>
Large-scale [[debt restructuring]] was needed urgently, since the high-interest bonds had become unpayable. The Argentine government met severe challenges trying to [[refinancing|refinance]] its debt, however. Creditors (many of them private citizens in Spain, Italy, Germany, Japan, the United States, and other countries, who had [[investment|invested]] their [[saving]]s and [[retirement]] [[pension]]s in debt [[Bond (finance)|bonds]]) denounced the default; this included bondholders from Argentina itself, estimated to compose about a fourth of affected bondholders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.clarin.com/diario/2005/01/10/um/m-901690.htm|title=Los bonistas argentinos, entre entablar juicios o esperar un fracaso del canje|work=Clarín|date=January 10, 2005}}</ref>
Economic recovery eventually allowed Argentina to offer large-scale debt swaps in 2005 and 2010; the first brought 76% of bonds out of default and the second, 91.3%.<ref name=jf/> The terms of the debt exchanges were not accepted by all private bondholders; the holders of around 7% of the defaulted bonds - known as "holdouts" - continued to seek full repayment. The [[IMF]] initially lobbied for the holdouts until Argentina's lump-sum repayment to the IMF in January 2006. Individual creditors worldwide, who represented about one third of this group, mobilized to seek repayment following the default. Among the most prominent were Task Force Argentina, an Italian retail bondholder association; and Mark Botsford, a private U.S. retail bondholder; and [[Kenneth Dart]], who unsuccessfully sued in 2003 to be paid $724 million for bonds purchased in 2001 for $120 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessobserverfl.com/print/Squeezing-Argentina/|title=Squeezing Argentina|work=Business Observer|date=13 February 2014|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> Dart renounced his U.S. citizenship in 1994 for [[tax avoidance]] purposes, and his interests in Argentina became the focus of [[tax evasion]] charges in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-05-21/billionaire-dart-s-argentine-foam-cup-unit-raided-by-tax-agents.html|title=Billionaire Dart's Argentine Unit Raided by Tax Agents|work=Bloomberg|date=21 May 2013}}</ref> Italian nationals had become the largest group of foreign retail investors in Argentine bonds when during the 1990s, banks in their country purchased $14 billion in bonds and then resold them to nearly half a million investors; the vast majority rejected the first swap but accepted the second.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-04-25/tired-italians-may-accept-anything-to-unload-argentina-s-defaulted-bonds.html|title=Tired Italians May `Accept Anything' to Unload Argentina's Defaulted Bonds|work=Bloomberg|date=April 25, 2010}}</ref>
===Background and holdout problem=== Upon default, Argentina's bondholders sued to be repaid 100% of their bonds' face value.<ref name=Benson>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-03-28/u-s-judge-vacates-2-2-billion-order-in-argentine-bond-case.html|title=Argentine Funds Can’t Be Seized by Bond Holders, Judge Says|work=Bloomberg|date=March 28, 2012|accessdate=August 29, 2013}}</ref><ref name=yahoo>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/argentina-offers-pay-debts-cash-bonds-040817493--finance.html|title= Argentina offers to pay debts with cash & bonds|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=March 30, 2013}}</ref><ref name=cepr>{{cite web|url=http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/the-americas-blog/vulture-turns-to-pirate-blocks-argentine-ship-from-leaving-ghana|title=Vulture Turns to Pirate: Blocks Argentine Ship from Leaving Ghana|work=CEPR blogs}}</ref> Among the bondholders were [[vulture funds]], who had [[Speculation|speculatively]] acquired US$1.3 billion of the bonds' total value on the [[secondary market]] for cents on the dollar after the 2001 default.<ref name=ips/><ref name=crazy>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2013/08/27/elliott-vs-argentina-enter-the-crazy/|title=Elliott vs Argentina: Enter the crazy|author=Salmon, Felix|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=August 27, 2013}}</ref> Vulture funds also owned a large quantity of [[credit default swap]]s (CDS) against Argentine bonds. This created a further incentive to not only trigger a default against Argentina; but also to undermine the value of the bonds themselves, as the CDS would pay out at a higher rate if the defaulted bonds decline to extremely low values.<ref name=crazy/>
The vulture funds held out for payment in full via [[litigation]] (hence their common description as "holdout" bondholders, or "holdouts"). Their legal tactics included seeking [[injunction]]s to [[attachment (law)|attach]] future payments to other bondholders by way of forcing Argentina to [[settlement (law)|settle]].<ref name=nyt/><ref name=cepr/><ref name=aba>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-04/bankers-group-supports-bond-trustee-in-argentina-appeal-1-.html|title=Bankers’ Group Supports Bond Trustee in Argentina Appeal|work=Bloomberg|date=January 5, 2013|accessdate=October 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name=phillips>{{cite web|url=http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/the-americas-blog/argentina-vs-the-vultures-what-you-need-to-know|title=Argentina vs. the Vultures: What You Need to Know|work=CEPR|author=Arthur Phillips and Jake Johnston|date=April 2, 2013}}</ref><ref name=economist>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/business/displayStory.cfm?story_id=3715779|title=A victory by default?|work=The Economist|date=March 3, 2005|accessdate=October 12, 2013}}</ref> A similar strategy had been successfully pursued previously by vulture funds against [[Peru]] and a number of African nations,<ref name=economist/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jubileeusa.org/vulturefunds/vulture-fund-country-studies.html |title=Vulture Fund Case Studies: Peru and Elliott Associates |work=Jubilee USA Network |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015052539/http://www.jubileeusa.org/vulturefunds/vulture-fund-country-studies.html |archivedate=2013-10-15 }}</ref> as well as against corporations in the United States itself, such as [[Delphi Automotive]], which was forced to pay [[Paul Singer (businessman)|Paul Singer]]'s [[Elliott Management Corporation]] a return of over 3,000% on [[corporate bond]]s defaulted during the 2008 recession.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/carl-pope/romney-delphi-auto_b_2051373.html|title=Was Romney Blind to His Adviser's Vulture Fund?|work=[[Huffington Post]]|date=2 November 2012}}</ref> [[NML Capital Limited]], the [[Cayman Islands]]-based principal vulture funds in this dispute, is also owned by Singer. NML paid $49 million in the secondary market for bonds worth $832 million by 2014.<ref name=vice>{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/article/talons-out-argentina-desperately-fighting-vulture-funds-over-debt|title=Talons Out: Argentina Desperately Fighting "Vulture Funds" Over Debt|work=Vice News|date=June 18, 2014}}</ref> Its [[lobbying]] group, American Task Force Argentina, is the most prominent and best financed opponent of Argentine bond restructuring efforts, spending over $7 million lobbying [[U.S. Congress]]men and becoming the top campaign contributor to a number of these; the most prominent, former Western Hemisphere Subcommittee Chair [[Connie Mack IV]] (R-FL), became the main sponsor of a bill in 2012 designed to force Argentina to pay NML nearly $2 billion before losing his Senate bid that year.<ref name=cepr/> Their lobbying campaign also extends to Argentina, where NML Capital finances an [[NGO]] led by Laura Alonso, a [[Argentine Chamber of Deputies|Congresswoman]] affiliated with the right-wing [[Republican Proposal|PRO]] party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cadenaba.com.ar/nota.php?Id=13515|title=La Fundación de la diputada PRO, Laura Alonso recibió 100.000 dólares de fondo buitre|work=Cadena BA|date=January 21, 2013}}</ref>
In August 2013, the Government of Argentina lost a U.S. appeals court case and was told it had to repay the full face value amount to these holdouts.<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|title=Argentina loses $1.3bn debt court appeal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-23832247|publisher=BBC|date=25 August 2013}}</ref> Courts in Europe have backed Argentina on the basis of the [[Pari passu|equal terms]] clause, however.<ref name=belgium>{{cite web|url=http://www.telam.com.ar/english/notas/201307/39-a-belgian-court-ruled-in-favor-of-argentina-and-against-a-vulture-fund.html |title=A Belgian court ruled in favor of Argentina and against a vulture fund |work=Telam |date=July 11, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928011313/http://www.telam.com.ar/english/notas/201307/39-a-belgian-court-ruled-in-favor-of-argentina-and-against-a-vulture-fund.html |archivedate=September 28, 2013 }}</ref><ref name=france>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/26/argentina-debt-france-idUSL1N0FW1NZ20130726|title=France to back legal argument in Argentina case against creditors|agency=Reuters|date=July 26, 2013}}</ref><ref name=germany>{{cite web|url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/135798/german-court-rules-in-argentina-favour-against-vulture-funds-|title=German court rules in Argentina favour against Vulture Funds|work=Buenos Aires Herald|date=July 11, 2013}}</ref> A third debt restructuring offer to remaining holdouts on similar terms to the 2010 swap was announced on August 27, 2013.<ref name=lf>{{cite web|url=http://www.latinfinance.com/Article/3248220/Argentina-Offers-New-Swap-in-Pragmatic-Plan-B.html#.Uh04y23b3m4An|title=Argentina offers new swap in pragmatic Plan B|work=Latin Finance|date=August 27, 2013|accessdate=October 12, 2013}}</ref> However, meeting vulture funds' full face-value demands is problematic for Argentina, because although bonds held by vulture funds are a small share of the total (1.6%), such a settlement would lead to lawsuits from other bondholders demanding to be paid on similar terms under the agreement's "[[rights upon future offers]]" (RUFO) clause, effectively unwinding the settlement by allowing all bondholders payment in full, and creating an unaffordable liability of up to $120 billion more than at present.<ref name=swaps>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-08-01/argentina-default-triggers-1-billion-of-swaps-after-isda-ruling.html|title=Argentine Bonds Decline as Default Triggers $1 Billion of Swaps|work=Bloomberg|date=1 August 2014}}</ref>
As a result, Argentina has still not been able to raise finance on the international debt markets for fear that any money raised would be impounded by holdout lawsuits; their [[country risk]] borrowing cost premiums remain over 10%, much higher than comparable countries. Consequently, Argentina has been paying debt from [[Central Bank of Argentina|central bank]] reserves, has banned most retail purchases of dollars, limited imports, and ordered companies to repatriate money held abroad. Nevertheless, between 2003 and 2012 Argentina met [[Government debt|debt service]] payments totaling $173.7 billion, of which 81.5 billion was collected by bondholders, 51.2 billion by multilateral lenders such as the IMF and [[World Bank]], and 41 billion by Argentine government agencies. Public external debt denominated in foreign currencies (mainly in dollars and euros) accordingly fell from 150% of GDP in 2002 to 8.3% in 2013.<ref name=info/>
==Debt restructuring history==
===First restructuring (2005)=== [[File:Néstor Kirchner y Roberto Lavagna-Buenos Aires-23 de agosto de 2004.jpg|thumb|260px|President [[Néstor Kirchner]] and Economy Minister [[Roberto Lavagna]], who presented the first debt restructuring offer in 2005]] In 2001, Argentina defaulted on its foreign debt.<ref name=bbb>{{cite news|title=Venezuelan banks enjoy treasuries windfall|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6e8f3fce-928a-11da-977b-0000779e2340.html#axzz3ZTCiTC9c|accessdate=7 May 2015|work=Financial Times|date=31 January 2006}}</ref> In January 2005, the Argentine government offered the first [[debt restructuring]] to affected bondholders; nearly 76% of the defaulted bonds (US$62.5 billion) were thus exchanged and brought out of default. The exchange offered longer term [[accrual bond|par]], [[inflation-indexed bond|quasi-par]], and [[discount bond]]s - the latter with a [[haircut (finance)|much lower nominal value]] (25–35% of the original). The majority of the Argentine bond market thereafter became based on [[GDP-linked bond]]s, and investors, both foreign and domestic, netted record yields amid renewed growth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cronista.com/economiapolitica/El-PBI-subio-85-en-2010-y-asegura-pago-record-de-us-2.200-millones-a-inversores-20110119-0069.html |title=El PBI subió 8,5% en 2010 y asegura pago récord de u$s 2.200 millones a inversores |work=El Cronista Comercial |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63mmSxU50?url=http://www.cronista.com/economiapolitica/El-PBI-subio-85-en-2010-y-asegura-pago-record-de-us-2.200-millones-a-inversores-20110119-0069.html |archivedate=2011-12-08 }}</ref> One of the largest single investors in Argentine bonds following these developments was [[Venezuela]], which bought a total of more than $5 billion in restructured Argentine bonds from 2005 to 2007.<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSN0835483220070808|title=Chavez keeps up South American energy diplomacy|agency= Reuters|date=Aug 8, 2007}}</ref> Between 2001-2006, Venezuela was the largest single buyer of Argentina's debt.<ref name=bbb/>
In 2005 and 2006, [[Banco Occidental de Descuento]] and [[Fondo Común]], owned by Venezuelan bankers Victor Vargas Irausquin and Victor Gill Ramirez respectively, bought most of Argentina's outstanding bonds and resold them on to the market.<ref name=bbb/> The banks bought $100 million worth of Argentine bonds and resold the bonds for a profit of approximately $17 million.<ref name=fff>{{cite web|last1=Coronel|first1=Gustavo|title=Corruption, Mismanagement, and Abuse of Power in HugoChávez's Venezuela (Development Policy Analysis)|url=http://www.cato.org/pubs/dpa/html/dpa2/dpa200007.html|website=Center for Global Liberty & Prosperity|publisher=The Cato Institute|location=Washington, D.C.|page=7|date=27 November 2006}}</ref> People who criticize Vargas have said that he made a $1 billion "backroom deal" with swaps of Argentine bonds as a sign of his friendship with Chavez.<ref name=aaa>{{cite news|last1=Padgett|first1=Tim|title=The Dead Polo Ponies and Their Millionaire Owner|work=Time Magazine|publisher=Time Inc.|url= http://content.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1893280,00.html|accessdate=7 May 2015|date=23 April 2009}}</ref> The ''Financial Times'' interviewed financial analysts in the United States who said that the banks profited from the resale of the bonds; the Venezuelan government did not profit.<ref name=fff/>
Bondholders who had accepted the 2005 swap (three out of four did so) saw the value of their bonds rise 90% by 2012,<ref name=snub/> and these continued to rise strongly during 2013.<ref name=lf/>
===IMF repayment=== During the restructuring process, the [[International Monetary Fund]] was considered a "privileged creditor", that is, all debt was recognized and paid in full. During 2005 Argentina shifted from a policy of constant negotiation and refinancing with the IMF to payment in full, taking advantage of a large and growing fiscal surplus due to rising commodity prices and economic output, with the acknowledged intention of gaining financial independence from the IMF.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2005/07/28/um/m-1022668.htm|title=El Gobierno defiende el desendeudamiento con el Fondo|work=Clarín|date=July 28, 2005 |accessdate=August 29, 2013}}</ref>
President [[Néstor Kirchner]] on December 15, 2005, announced his intention of liquidating all the remaining debt to the IMF, in a single payment of US$9.81 billion, initially planned to take place before the end of the year (a similar move had been announced by Brazil two days before, and it is understood that the two measures were to be coordinated).<ref name=chau>{{cite web|url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-60572-2005-12-16.html|title=Todo en un pago y chau al Fondo|work=Página/12|date=December 16, 2005}}</ref>
Argentina under the Kirchner administration had already reduced its debt to the IMF from $15.5 billion in 2003<ref name=economist/> to $10.5 billion at the time of this announcement.<ref name=chau/> The last and largest remaining share of the IMF debt, about $9.5 billion, was paid on January 3, 2006. The debt was in fact denominated in [[special drawing rights]] (SDR; a unit employed by the IMF and calculated over a basket of currencies). The [[Banco Central de la República Argentina|Argentine Central Bank]] called on the [[Bank for International Settlements]] in [[Basel|Basel, Switzerland]], where a part of its currency reserves were deposited, to act as its agent. The BIS bought 3.78 billion SDR (equivalent to about $5.4 billion) from 16 central banks and ordered their transfer to the IMF. The rest (2.874 billion SDR or $4.1 billion) was transferred from Argentina's account in the IMF, deposited in the U.S. Federal Reserve.<ref name=asia>{{cite web|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Global_Economy/LG29Dj05.html|title=Pegs, boards and the IMF|work=Asia Times|date=July 29, 2010|accessdate=October 12, 2013}}</ref>
The payment served to cancel the debt installments that were to be paid in 2006 ($5.1 billion), 2007 ($4.6 billion), and 2008 ($432 million). This disbursement represented 8.8% of the total Argentine public debt and decreased the Central Bank's reserves by one third (from $28 billion to $18.6 billion). According to the official announcement, it also saved about a billion dollars in interest, though the actual savings amounted to $842 million (since the reserves that were in the BIS were until then receiving interest payments).<ref name=chau/> One of the largest single investors in Argentine bonds following these Venezuela bought a total of more than $5 billion in restructured Argentine bonds from 2005 to 2007.<ref name="reuters.com"/>
The initial announcement was made in a surprise press conference. President Kirchner said that, with this payment, "we bury an ignominious past of eternal, infinite indebtment." Many of those present later called the decision "historic". The head of the IMF, [[Rodrigo Rato]], saluted it, though remarking that Argentina "faces important challenges ahead". [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]] [[John W. Snow]] said that this move "shows good faith" on the part of the Argentine government.<ref name=chau/> [[Nobel Economics Prize]] laureate [[Joseph Stiglitz]] repeatedly criticized the IMF and supported the Argentine strategies on the debt restructuring, but opposed the disindebtment policy, suggesting instead that the IMF should receive the same treatment as the other creditors. Local criticism of the IMF debt paydown centered around the cost, which made funds unavailable for productive purposes within Argentina or to come to terms with outstanding creditors; and second, that the government traded cheap IMF credits for new emissions of public debt at much higher interest rates.<ref name=asia/> Following the initial surprise and mixed reactions local markets rallied, with the [[MERVAL]] index growing more in January 2006 than in all of 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/776913-en-enero-la-bolsa-gano-mas-que-en-todo-2005|title=En enero, la Bolsa ganó más que en todo 2005|work=La Nación|date=January 31, 2006}}</ref>
The Ministry of Economy reported in June 2005 that the total official Argentine public debt was down by $63.5 billion from the first semester to $126.5 billion as a result of the restructuring process; of this, 46% was denominated in dollars, 36% in pesos, and 11% in [[euro]]s and other currencies. Due to the full payment of the IMF debt and several other adjustments, as of January 2006 the total figure decreased further to $124.3 billion; bonds not exchanged in 2005 accounted for $23.4 billion, of which 12.7 billion were already overdue. The Central Bank's reserves surpassed their pre-payment levels on September 27, 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/economia/nota.asp?nota_id=844220|title=El Central recuperó las reservas del pago al Fondo Monetario|work=La Nación|date=September 28, 2006}}</ref>
A similar agreement was reached eight years later with the [[Paris Club]] of creditor nations (the last remaining Argentine debt still in default besides bonds held by holdouts) on debt repayment totaling $9 billion including penalties and interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/165759/government-prepays-paris-club-as-a-sign-of-good-faith-over-default|title=Government pre-pays Paris Club as a sign of good faith over default|work=Buenos Aires Herald|date=30 July 2014|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref>
===Second debt swap: debt exchange reopens (2010)=== On April 15, 2010, the debt exchange was re-opened to bondholders who rejected the 2005 swap; 67% of these latter accepted the swap, leaving 7% as holdouts.<ref name=jf/> Holdouts continued to put pressure on the government by attempting to seize Argentine assets abroad,<ref name=forbes>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/afontevecchia/2012/10/05/the-real-story-behind-the-argentine-vessel-in-ghana-and-how-hedge-funds-tried-to-seize-the-presidential-plane/|title=The real story behind the Argentine vessel in Ghana and how hedge funds tried to seize the presidential plane|work=Forbes}}</ref> and by suing to attach future Argentine payments on restructured debt to receive better treatment than cooperating creditors.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=phillips/><ref name=reuters>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/22/uk-argentina-debt-idUSLNE91L00B20130222|title=What Argentina's fight with holdout creditors is all about|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=February 22, 2013}}</ref>
A total of approximately US$12.86 billion of eligible debt was tendered into the exchange launched in April 2010; this represented 69.5% of outstanding bonds still held by holdouts.<ref>{{cite news|author=Richard Wray|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/apr/16/argentina-to-repay-2001-debt|title=Argentina to repay 2001 debt as Greece struggles to avoid default|work=The Guardian|date=April 16, 2010}}</ref> A total of 152 types of bonds in seven different currencies under eight distinct jurisdictions were issued during the two debt exchanges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.embajadaabierta.com/?p=1883#sthash.8iV97Ip3.dpuf|title= Radiografía de un fondo buitre ensañado con Argentina|work=Embajada Abierta|author=[[Jorge Argüello]]|date=3 March 2012|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref> The 2010 re-opening thus brought the total amount of debt restructured to 92.6% (the original 2005 debt exchange restructured 76.2% of Argentine government debt in default since 2001). The final settlement of the 2010 debt exchange took place on August 11, for bondholders that didn't participate in the early [[tranche]] that closed on May 14 and settled on May 17.<ref name=jf/>
==Holdout bondholders== Although around 93% of bondholders accepted reduced repayments (typically being repaid only 30% of the face value of bonds), a minority owning around 7% of the debt (US$4 billion), mostly [[hedge fund]]s and [[vulture fund]]s, continued to argue in court that they were due repayment in full, and held out for full repayment, eventually winning their case.<ref name="Benson"/>
[[NML Capital Limited]], a [[Cayman Islands]]-based [[offshore banking|offshore]] unit of [[Paul Singer (businessman)|Paul Singer]]'s [[Elliott Management Corporation]], purchased many holdings in 2008, paying an estimated $49 million for one series of bonds whose face value was over $220 million;<ref name=phillips/> with the subsequent boom in Argentine bond values, this face value grew to $832 million by 2014.<ref name=vice/> They in turn established the American Task Force Argentina [[lobbying]] group against Argentine bond restructuring efforts,<ref name=cepr/> and sued to enjoin Argentina's ongoing payments to the bondholders who had participated in the earlier restructurings.<ref name=nyt/>
===Holdout parties win the right to be repaid in full=== During the 2000s NML Capital's lawyers initially obtained several large judgments against Argentina, all of which were affirmed on appeal. These rulings found that the holdout bondholders in the case were entitled to be repaid the full face value of the bonds they held, rather than alternative amounts such as the reduced settlements negotiated in 2005 and 2010, or the amounts they had purchased the bonds for.
After defaulting, Argentina continued to pay its renegotiated bondholders, but not the holdout bondholders who had rejected settlement. As Argentina refused to pay the holdout creditors at full value, the holdouts initially resorted to lawsuits to seize Argentine government assets abroad – notably Central Bank deposits in the [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.mercopress.com/2012/06/26/us-supreme-court-rules-in-favour-of-argentina-and-unfreezes-funds|title=US Supreme Court rules in favour of Argentina and unfreezes funds|work=MercoPress|date=26 June 2012}}</ref> the [[Tango 01|presidential airplane]], and the {{ship|ARA|Libertad|Q-2|6}}.<ref name=forbes/> The ''Libertad'', an [[Argentine Navy]] training frigate, was arrested (though not seized) at the behest of NML Capital for ten weeks in late 2012 in the port of [[Tema]], [[Ghana]], until the [[International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea]] ruled unanimously that it be released.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/a6dfae3a-5abb-11e2-b60e-00144feab49a.html|title=Argentine naval frigate returns home|author=Daniel Schweimler|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=10 January 2013}}</ref> Eventually this approach proved fruitless. The holdout bondholders soon discovered that due to a number of [[sovereign immunity]] laws, it was impossible to actually [[Enforcement of foreign judgments|enforce their judgments]] by seizing the handful of Argentine assets still within the reach of U.S. jurisdiction.
In a lawsuit filed by NML, the lower UK courts found that Argentina had state immunity. Before 2011, Elliott successfully appealed the case to the [[UK Supreme Court]], which ruled that Elliott had the right to attempt to seize Argentine property in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Elliott_WSJ_2011">{{cite web | url =https://blogs.wsj.com/deals/2011/12/12/hedge-fund-elliott-associates-takes-vietnam-to-court/ | title =Hedge Fund Elliott Associates Takes Vietnam to Court | last =Steger | first =Isabella | date =December 12, 2011 | website =wsj.com | publisher =[[The Wall Street Journal]] | access-date = August 13, 2016}}</ref>
===Holdout parties win the right to have "equal payment" terms enforced=== The basis of the holdout bondholders' next approach arose from oversights on Argentina's part, due to both its economic history and partly from the legal wording chosen by the Argentina's government.
Because Argentina had been historically so unstable, it would have been difficult for it to solicit investors to buy bonds in Buenos Aires under Argentine jurisdiction, as few external investors trusted Argentina courts to enforce bonds against their own government. This consideration led Argentina to transfer the issue of bonds to New York, under United States law, on April 20, 1976, as were most subsequent bond issues.<ref name=bae>{{cite web|url=http://opinion.infobae.com/andres-asiain/tag/rights-upon-future-offers-rufo/|title=El fallo Griesa y la operación buitre|work=Infobae|date=September 10, 2013}}</ref> The bonds were therefore issued under a special kind of bond contract, a "Fiscal Agency Agreement" that was drafted by Argentina's U.S. attorneys under [[Law of New York|the law of the state of New York]]. The FAA stipulated that the repayments on the bonds were to be made by Argentina through a trustee, [[The Bank of New York Mellon]], which meant that the U.S. courts did have jurisdiction over that party to issue injunctive relief.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://qctimes.com/business/argentina-s-debt-fight-what-it-is-why-it-matters/article_bd48d454-3079-52fc-b750-6995fad08309.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140623203912/http://qctimes.com/business/argentina-s-debt-fight-what-it-is-why-it-matters/article_bd48d454-3079-52fc-b750-6995fad08309.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 23, 2014 |title=Argentina's debt fight: What it is, why it matters |work=Quad City Business Journal |date=June 23, 2014 |accessdate=July 31, 2014 }}</ref>
In the Fiscal Agency Agreement, Argentina's attorneys included a boilerplate ''[[pari passu]]'' clause, but neglected to include a [[collective action clause]]. ''Pari passu'' is a term generally used to signify equal priority or treatment, and a collective action clause would have obligated any holdouts to accept the generally offered terms if [[supermajority|enough other bondholders]] agreed to accept them. As a result, the holdouts realized that while Argentina could not force the holdouts to accept the terms in the 2005 or 2010 restructurings, NML could use the ''pari passu'' clause to force Argentina to choose between paying all its bondholders (including NML) or none of them.
NML Capital therefore sued Argentina in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York]] (i.e., a federal trial court) by invoking that court's [[diversity jurisdiction]] as well as [[Forum selection clause|forum selection]] and [[choice of law clause]]s in the Fiscal Agency Agreement itself.
====''Pari passu'' litigation case==== Federal district judge [[Thomas P. Griesa]] was assigned to hear the case. The crucial expression ''pari passu'' had not previously been interpreted in any published decision by the [[judiciary of New York|courts of the state of New York]], but there is no way in U.S. federal civil procedure for a federal district court to ''directly'' transfer a case to state court if it had not originally started there. (By way of contrast, if NML Capital had sued Argentina in a New York state court, Argentina would have had the option to "[[Removal jurisdiction|remove]]" the case to federal court.) Instead, the district court was required by ''[[Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins]]'' (1938) to make an "[[Erie doctrine|Erie guess]]" as to how a [[New York Supreme Court|New York state trial court]] would interpret that clause by applying general principles of contract law in the state of New York as articulated in the published decisions of the [[New York Court of Appeals]] and the [[New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division]]. The district court ruled in NML Capital's favor and issued broad permanent injunctions against Argentina and the bond trustee. The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] (the federal appellate court with jurisdiction over New York) in turn affirmed the district court's interpretation, but did not exercise its optional right to certify that specific issue to the New York Court of Appeals for a ruling on New York state law.
According to the Second Circuit's opinion issued on October 26, 2012 (signed by senior circuit judge [[Barrington Daniels Parker, Jr.]]), Paragraph 1(c) of the 1994 version of Argentina's Fiscal Agency Agreement was as follows:
:The Securities will constitute ... direct, unconditional, unsecured and unsubordinated obligations of the Republic and shall at all times rank ''pari passu'' without any preference among themselves. The payment obligations of the Republic under the Securities shall at all times rank at least equally with all its other present and future unsecured and unsubordinated External Indebtedness....<ref name="NMLCapital">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=13527582518963109632 NML Capital, Ltd. v. Republic of Argentina]'', 699 F.3d 246 (2nd Cir. 2012).</ref>
The Second Circuit interpreted this clause under New York law and concluded "that in pairing the two sentences of its Pari Passu Clause, the FAA manifested an intention to protect bondholders from more than just formal subordination .... the two sentences ... protect against different forms of discrimination: the issuance of other superior debt (first sentence) and the giving of priority to other payment obligations (second sentence)."<ref name="NMLCapital"/> Argentina had argued the entire clause was intended to protect only against the ''first'' type of discrimination; the Second Circuit held that Argentina's approach was invalid because it ignored the critical differences in wording between the two sentences, treated the second sentence as redundant, and in turn violated New York's rule that "a contract should not be interpreted in such a way as would leave one of its provisions substantially without force or effect."<ref name="NMLCapital"/> Thus, the Second Circuit affirmed the trial court's decision that Argentina could either pay ''all'' its bondholders or ''none'', but could not pay only those who cooperated with the 2005 and 2010 restructurings and ignore the rest.<ref name="NMLCapital"/>
Thus in 2012 (affirmed on appeal 2013), the courts ruled that paying the settled bondholders but not the holdouts was a breach of Argentina's agreement and discriminated against the holdout bondholders.<ref name=reuters/>
Furthermore, the Second Circuit held that the trial court's injunctions did not violate Argentina's sovereign immunity because they merely enforced the prohibition against both formal and informal ''subordination'' of any part of the debt to any other debt: "They do not attach, arrest, or execute upon any property .... the Injunctions do not require Argentina to pay any bondholder any amount of money; nor do they limit the other uses to which Argentina may put its fiscal reserves. In other words, the Injunctions do not transfer any dominion or control over sovereign property to the court."<ref name="NMLCapital"/>
As of February 2013, after further decisions by the district court, the case came again before the Second Circuit.<ref name=Bloomberg022613>{{cite news|title=Argentina Seeks Relief From U.S. Court in Debt Fight|url= http://www.businessweek.com/news/2013-02-26/argentina-seeks-relief-from-u-dot-s-dot-court-in-debt-fight|newspaper=Bloomberg|date=February 26, 2013|author=Bob Van Voris|accessdate=August 29, 2013}}</ref> The decision of the appeals court was adverse and a motion for rehearing by a [[en banc|full panel]] was denied on March 26.<ref name=Bloomberg032613>{{cite news|title=Argentina Loses Bid for Full-Court Rehearing in Bond Appeal |accessdate=August 29, 2013|url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/bloomberg/article/Argentina-Loses-Bid-for-Full-Court-Rehearing-in-4386083.php|newspaper=Bloomberg|date=March 26, 2013|author=Bob Van Voris|author2=Katia Porzecanski}}</ref>
On August 23, 2013, the Second Circuit (in another opinion also signed by Judge Parker) affirmed the lower court's latest ruling clarifying the scope of the permanent injunctions.<ref name="NMLCapital2">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12349482740132205657 NML Capital, Ltd. v. Republic of Argentina]'', 727 F.3d 230 (2nd Cir. 2013).</ref> The court implied at the start of its opinion that since Argentina had taken a calculated risk to enjoy the benefit of New York law (i.e., a lower interest rate), it now had to bear the burden of New York law as well: "In order to enhance the marketability of the bonds, Argentina made a series of promises to the purchasers."<ref name="NMLCapital2"/> Among those promises in the 1994 Fiscal Agency Agreement were the ''pari passu'' clause, the aforementioned forum selection and choice-of-law clauses expressly referencing New York, as well as a promise of the free transferability of the bonds to any transferee, regardless of whether that transferee was a "university endowment, a so-called 'vulture fund,' or a widow or an orphan."<ref name="NMLCapital2"/> In other words, as the drafter of the Fiscal Agency Agreement, Argentina could have easily avoided the situation it found itself in by writing a different ''pari passu'' clause, omitting the transferability clause, including anti-assignment clauses (e.g., a clause providing that assignees could only recover the amount actually paid rather than face value of the debt), or writing the contract under the law of a different jurisdiction altogether, with the understanding that rational investors would have demanded higher interest rates in exchange for any of these things.
After refuting all of Argentina's arguments on the merits, the Second Circuit concluded: "We do not believe the outcome of this case threatens to steer bond issuers away from the New York marketplace ... We believe that the interest — one widely shared in the financial community — in maintaining New York's status as one of the foremost commercial centers is advanced by requiring debtors, including foreign debtors, to pay their debts."<ref name="NMLCapital2"/>
Notably, when it came to looking at big-picture public policy issues, both Second Circuit opinions examined them only through the lens of federal procedural law (i.e., whether the injunctions were an inequitable remedy) as opposed to the substantive rules of New York state contractual law. Although New York recognizes several defenses to the enforceability of a contract like [[unconscionability]], those defenses are usually available only to the weaker party at the time of contract formation, the party who did ''not'' write the contract (i.e., the bondholders), which explains why they were not discussed in the Second Circuit's opinions. If those defenses are unavailable (for example, because the party resisting enforcement was the one who wrote the contract), New York courts will mechanically enforce the plain language of a contract regardless of its harshness because "a court is not free to alter the contract to reflect its personal notions of fairness and equity."<ref>''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=3663883735767166212 Greenfield v. Philles Records]'', 98 N.Y.2d 562, 570 (2002).</ref>
The [[United States Supreme Court]] repeatedly denied Argentina's petitions for certiorari, on October 7, 2013 and June 16, 2014,<ref>[http://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=4272&context=californialawreview John Muse-Fisher, ''Starving the Vultures: NML Capital v. Republic of Argentina and Solutions to the Problem of Distressed-Debt Funds''], 102 Cal. L. Rev. 1671 (2014).</ref> meaning that it was effectively refusing to hear Argentina's appeals from the Second Circuit's decisions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/07/us-usa-court-argentina-idUSBRE9960ES20131007|title=U.S. Supreme Court won't hear Argentina bond dispute appeal|agency=Reuters|date=October 7, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/business/world/a/24252281/us-supreme-court-rejects-argentine-debt-appeals/|title=US Supreme Court rejects Argentine debt appeals|date=16 June 2014|website=Yahoo!|agency=AP}}</ref> The petition denied on June 16 had presented two issues: (1) sovereign immunity and (2) the Second Circuit's decision to simply affirm the trial court's ''Erie'' guess as opposed to exercising the option to certify that issue to the New York Court of Appeals.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Solomon|first1=Steven Davidoff|title=Argentina Takes Its Debt Case to the U.S. Supreme Court|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/02/25/argentina-takes-its-debt-case-to-the-u-s-supreme-court/|accessdate=3 August 2014|work=The New York Times|date=25 February 2014}}</ref>
On the same day it denied to review the injunction, the U.S. Supreme Court affirmed Judge Griesa's worldwide [[discovery (law)|discovery order]] in ''[[Republic of Argentina v. NML Capital, Ltd.]]''<ref>[http://harvardlawreview.org/2014/11/republic-of-argentina-v-nml-capital-ltd/ ''The Supreme Court, 2013 Term - Leading Cases''], 128 Harv. L. Rev. 381 (2014)</ref>
Citigroup, which has operations in both New York and in Argentina, was caught in the middle, being required to conform to both New York and Argentine law, an international [[conflict of laws|conflict of law]]. The trial court has granted temporary relief to the bank, allow payment of a few of the interest payments due to holdout bondholders,<ref name=NYT03221>{{cite news|author=Alexandra Stevenson|title=Citigroup Says Court Order Will Let It Pay Argentine Bond Interest|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/23/business/dealbook/citigroup-says-court-order-will-let-it-pay-argentine-bond-interest.html|accessdate=March 23, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=March 22, 2015|format=Dealbook blog}}</ref> but the obligation to repay all holdouts as the cost of continuing to service Argentine bonds had resulted in a decision to terminate its Argentine debt servicing operation absent legal relief.<ref name=NYT031715>{{cite news|author1=Alexandra Stevenson|title=As Argentina and Hedge Funds Battle, Citigroup Bows Out|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/18/business/dealbook/citigroup-in-middle-of-hedge-fund-argentina-face-off-to-close-its-argentine-business.html|accessdate=March 23, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=March 17, 2015}}</ref>
===Argentina 2014 "selective default"=== The ''Pari passu'' ruling had a grave impact on Argentina's route out of economic difficulty. The issue perceived by Argentina was that the agreement also included a "[[rights upon future offers]]" ("RUFO") clause. The effect of such a clause was that, if a later settlement paid more, or on better terms, all existing settlements would be repaid on the improved terms. This was intended to reassure bondholders that it was safe to settle early, and reduce the incentive to hold out for a better later offer.
As a result of the earlier rulings for the holdout bondholders, Argentina now faced a situation whereby: # The 7% of bonds held by the "Holdout" bondholders had to be paid at full face value, whereas the other 93% had agreed to be repaid around 30% of the bonds' face value; # The 93% of renegotiated bonds could not have repayments made without also making repayments (on a larger scale) to the 7% of holdouts; # Any repayments to the holdouts related to full face value would potentially trigger all earlier bondholders being entitled to repayments at full face value as well, effectively unwinding the entire intent of the renegotiations of 2000 - 2010, and creating an extra liability of $100 billion that Argentina could not afford to incur.
The U.S. judicial ''pari passu'' ruling therefore forced Argentina to miss the scheduled bond payments being managed from New York, as from July 30, 2014 (bonds issued under Argentine law (paid through [[Citibank Argentina]])<ref name=muddled/> and bonds issued under European Law (paid through [[Euroclear]] and [[Clearstream]]), were not affected.<ref name=Europe/>). This in turn caused Argentina to be declared in selective default by [[Standard & Poor's]] and in restricted default by [[Fitch Ratings|Fitch]], meaning that some Argentine bondholders were receiving payment while others now weren't.<ref name=selective/>
===Responses to the ruling and 2014 default===
====By Argentina==== President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] stated after the latter denial of certiorari that her country had an obligation to pay its creditors, but not to become the victims of [[extortion]] by speculators; even if Argentina can't use the U.S. financial system to do so, she said, teams of experts are working on ways to avoid such a default and keep Argentina's promises.<ref>{{cite news|date=16 June 2014|website= www.sfgate.com|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/politics/article/High-court-rejects-Argentina-s-appeal-over-debt-5555358.php|title=Argentina: Won't submit to 'extortion' on debt|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> The expiration of Rights Upon Future Offers ([[RUFO]]) in December 2014 will preclude other bondholders from suing for better terms should the Argentine Government and the vulture funds settle, making such a settlement all the more likely after that date should the dispute continue.<ref name=bae/>
=====International Court of Justice case===== In August 2014, Argentina filed a case at the [[International Court of Justice]], alleging that through its court system's decision, the United States had "violat[ed] its sovereign immunity" and breached "[the] obligation not to use or encourage measures of economic and political action to force the sovereign will of another State",<ref name="cnn1">[http://cnnespanol.cnn.com/2014/08/07/argentina-solicita-demanda-contra-ee-uu-en-la-haya/ Argentina solicita un proceso contra EE.UU. en La Haya] ["Argentina requests a lawsuit against USA at The Hague"], CNN</ref><ref name=wjs1>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/argentina-sues-u-s-in-international-court-of-justice-over-debt-dispute-1407431003|title=Argentina Sues U.S. in International Court of Justice Over Debt Dispute|author=Ken Parks|date=7 August 2014|work=WSJ|accessdate=14 April 2016}}</ref> and was responsible for permitting judicial [[malpractice]] and [[Competence (law)|gross incompetence]] in allowing two small hedge funds to trigger a needless default against most other bondholders.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/11004486/Argentina-accuses-US-of-judicial-malpractice-for-triggering-needless-default.html|title=Argentina accuses US of judicial malpractice for triggering needless default|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=31 July 2014}}</ref> Information was likewise requested from the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] concerning the possibility of [[securities fraud]] involving the bonds by plaintiffs in the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telam.com.ar/english/notas/201408/2874-argentina-will-request-the-us-securities-exchange-commission-to-investigate-financial-fraud.html|title=Argentina will request the U.S. Securities Exchange Commission to investigate financial fraud|work=Telam|date=4 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808050722/http://www.telam.com.ar/english/notas/201408/2874-argentina-will-request-the-us-securities-exchange-commission-to-investigate-financial-fraud.html|archivedate=8 August 2014|df=}}</ref> Observers note that the United States must consent to the case being heard, which has only happened 22 times in the ICJ's 68 years of existence,<ref name=cnn1/><ref name=wjs1/> and a Latin American and international law specialist at [[Oxford Analytica]] observed to media that, "From the point of view of the U.S. government, the New York court system has dealt with a contractual dispute in which the executive [branch] cannot intervene. It's a dispute governed by a contract, not by a treaty or international law".<ref name=wjs1/>
====By other organizations and countries==== The decision was likewise rejected by the [[Organization of American States]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/the-americas-blog/us-on-its-own-once-again-at-oas-meeting-on-argentinean-sovereign-debt|author=Alexander Main|title=U.S. on Its Own, Once Again, at OAS Meeting on Argentine Sovereign Debt|work=CEPR|date=9 July 2014|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref> the [[Group of 77|G-77]] (133 nations),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telam.com.ar/english/notas/201406/2556-unified-support-of-g77china-summit-to-argentina-on-malvinas-and-vulture-funds.html |title=Unified support of G77+China Summit to Argentina on Malvinas and vulture funds |work=Telam |date=15 June 2014 |accessdate=31 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808044435/http://www.telam.com.ar/english/notas/201406/2556-unified-support-of-g77china-summit-to-argentina-on-malvinas-and-vulture-funds.html |archivedate=8 August 2014 }}</ref> and the [[Council on Foreign Relations]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.mercopress.com/2014/06/26/us-council-of-foreign-affairs-supports-argentina-blasts-judge-griesa|title=US Council of Foreign Affairs supports Argentina, blasts Judge Griesa|work=MercoPress|date=26 June 2014}}</ref> as well as by bondholders whose payments were stopped by the Griesa court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-249549-2014-06-27.html|title=Griesa les tira a los rehenes|work=Página/12|date=27 June 2014|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law360.com/articles/553135/argentina-euro-bondholders-seek-exemption-from-us-courts|title=Argentina Euro Bondholders Seek Exemption From US Courts|work=Law 360|date=30 June 2014|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref>
====Financial responses==== Large banks, investors, and the [[U.S. Treasury Department]] objected to the federal courts' decisions and expressed concern over losses that could be incurred by bondholders and others, as well over disruption in the bond markets. Vladimir Werning, executive director for Latin American research at [[JPMorgan Chase]], observed that vulture funds "are trying to block the payments system" in the United States itself, something "unprecedented in the New York jurisdiction." Kevin Heine, a spokesman for [[Bank of New York Mellon]], which handles Argentina's international bond payments, said the ruling "will create unrest in the credit markets and result in cascades of litigation, which is precisely the opposite effect that an injunction should have."<ref name=nyt/> The [[American Bankers Association]] agreed, noting that "permitting injunctions that preclude pre-existing obligations whenever expedient to enforce a judgment against the debtor will have significantly adverse consequences for the financial system."<ref name=aba/>
A consortium of Argentine banks, led by Argentine Banking Association (Adeba) President [[Jorge Horacio Brito|Jorge Brito]], meanwhile presented their own settlement offer on July 30, by which all vulture fund bond holdings in dispute would be purchased in installments for a total of US$1.4 billion, but the offer was refused; [[Citibank]], [[JP Morgan Chase]], and [[HSBC]] joined efforts to repurchase vulture fund holdings on August 1.<ref name="Ambito_Intermeido_2014">{{cite web|url=http://www.ambito.com/noticia.asp?id=751755|title=Cuarto intermedio en NY por acuerdo entre privados|work=Ámbito|date=30 July 2014|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref> The [[International Swaps and Derivatives Association|ISDA]], of which Singer's Elliott hedge fund is one of 15 bank members, granted Singer and fellow vulture fund plaintiff Aurelius Capital [[Credit default swap|CDS]] insurance payout of $1 billion on August 1.<ref name=swaps/>
==Impact of deadlocked bond repayments==
===Impact on Argentina=== The dispute limited Argentina's access to foreign credit markets as well; in October 2012 Argentina's theoretical borrowing costs were 10.7%, double the average for developing countries.<ref name=Benson/> Although Argentina has not raised money on the money markets since the default, the state-owned oil company [[YPF]] has already placed debt in the financial markets to finance its investment program in years to come.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lmneuquen.com.ar/noticias/2012/11/9/ypf-coloco-deuda-por-750-millones-de-pesos_168182|title=YPF colocó deuda por 750 millones de pesos|work=La Mañana Neuquén|date=November 9, 2012}}</ref>
===Wider implications for the financial system=== The possibility that holdout creditors can attach future payments on restructured debt and receive better treatment than cooperating creditors distorts incentives, can derail efforts for a cooperative restructuring,<ref name=reuters/> and may ultimately lead to the United States no longer being viewed as a safe place to issue sovereign debt.<ref name=stiglitz>{{cite web|url=http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/argentina-s-debt-and-american-courts-by-joseph-e--stiglitz|title=The Vultures' Victory|author=Joseph Stiglitz|date=September 4, 2013|accessdate=October 12, 2013}}</ref>
The Second Circuit has acknowledged that New York Judiciary Law Section 489 (descended from an 1813 statute) appears to facially prohibit "essentially all 'secondary' transactions in debt instruments where the purchaser had an intent to enforce the debt obligation through litigation," but then ruled in a 1999 decision involving Elliott Management's earlier case against Peru that the history of that section as interpreted in New York state courts revealed that it was intended only to prohibit purchases made with the ''sole'' intent of bringing a lawsuit ''in and of itself''.<ref name="ElliottAssoc">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=7537030642058084794 Elliott Associates, LP v. Banco De La Nacion],'' 194 F. 3d 363, 372 (2nd Cir. 1999).</ref> That is, the New York Legislature was trying to stop attorneys or debt collectors from exploiting cost-shifting clauses in worthless promissory notes to obtain judgments for minuscule amounts (i.e., the face value of the notes) that also awarded massive costs incurred in the course of litigation.<ref name="ElliottAssoc"/> Section 489 does not apply to purchases made with the primary intent of collecting on the face value of the instrument, where litigation is merely a means to that end.<ref name="ElliottAssoc"/> The [[United Kingdom]], however, permanently banned the use of its courts for suits by vulture funds in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Al Jazeera America]]|url= http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/3/22/the-end-of-vulturefunds.html|title=The end of vulture funds?|date=22 March 2014|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref> As of 2014 70% of the world's sovereign bonds are issued in New York, and 22% in [[London]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://therealnews.com/t2/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=74&jumival=12142|title=US Courts Defend Rights of Vulture Funds Over Argentina|work=[[The Real News]]|date=23 July 2014|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref>
According to ''[[Reuters]]'' in 2013, the case is likely to be of particular importance in cases in which the creditors are being asked to accept substantial debt and debt service reduction, though it is unclear given the special circumstances of the Elliot/NML case whether it will be broadly applicable to holdouts in other restructurings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2013/08/23/elliott-vs-argentina-its-not-over-yet/|title=Elliott vs Argentina: It's not over yet|author=Felix Salmon|agency=Reuters|date=August 23, 2013|accessdate=August 29, 2013}}</ref> The [[American Bankers Association]] warned that the district court's interpretation of the [[Pari passu|equal terms]] provision could enable a single creditor to thwart the implementation of an internationally supported restructuring plan, and thereby undermine the decades of effort the United States has expended to encourage a system of cooperative resolution of sovereign debt crises.<ref name=phillips/>
==Presidency of Mauricio Macri and default end (2015-2016)==
[[Mauricio Macri]] was elected president of Argentina in November 2015. He sought to negotiate with the holdouts and end the default, in order to return to the international capital markets and benefit the national economy.<ref name="FT_DealHoldouts"/> In early 2016, US courts ruled that Argentina must make full payments to four "holdout bondholders" (NML, [[Aurelius Capital Management]], [[Davidson Kempner Capital Management]], and [[Bracebridge Capital]]) by February 29.<ref name="nytimesgilbertargentinareachesdeal">{{cite news|last1=Gilbert|first1=Jonathan|last2=Stevenson|first2=Alexandra|title=Argentina Reaches Deal With Hedge Funds Over Debt|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/01/business/dealbook/argentina-reaches-deal-with-hedge-funds-over-debt.html|accessdate=March 11, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=February 29, 2016|quote=The four holdout firms, including Aurelius, a hedge fund run by Mark Brodsky, a former trader at Mr. Singer’s Elliott Management; Davidson Kempner; and Bracebridge Capital, have agreed not to try to prevent Argentina from raising new money, which it will need to do in order to pay the settlements it has made.}}</ref> Argentina made an offer to pay $6.5 billion to settle lawsuits on February 5, requesting that the prior ruling on payments be lifted.<ref name="NYT_dealbook_2016">{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/25/business/dealbook/hedge-funds-dealt-setback-as-us-sides-with-argentina.html?ref=world | title=Hedge Funds Dealt Setback as U.S. Sides With Argentina on Defaulted Bonds | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=March 24, 2016 | accessdate=March 25, 2016 | author=Stevenson, Alexandra}}</ref> Daniel Pollack announced in February 2016 that Argentina had reached an agreement with Paul Singer. The deal would still need to be ratified by the Argentine Congress.<ref name="FT_DealHoldouts">{{cite web|url= http://www.ft.com/fastft/2016/02/29/argentina-reaches-4-65bn-deal-with-holdouts/|title=Argentina reaches $4.65bn deal with holdouts|date=February 29, 2016|work=Financial Times|accessdate=February 29, 2016}}</ref> The deal would only last until April 14, 2016.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1875416-daniel-pollack-el-acuerdo-se-termina-si-el-pago-no-se-hace-el-14-de-abril Daniel Pollack: "El acuerdo se termina si el pago no se hace antes del 14 de abril"] {{es icon}}</ref>
Although ''[[Cambiemos]]'', Macri's political coalition, did not have a majority at either house of the Congress, the bill was approved by both of them in March. Many Peronist legislators supported it because the province governors would also benefit from access to international credit markets. With the bill approved, Argentina faced a court hearing in New York on April 13.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/1c1f696c-f6fc-11e5-9afe-dd2472ea263d.html#axzz44U7q7YSm|title=Argentina clears way for repayment of ‘holdout’ creditors|author=Benedict Mander|date=March 31, 2016|work=Financial Times|accessdate=March 31, 2016}}</ref> The court confirmed the ruling of Griesa, and allowed Argentina to pay to the bondholders of 2005, 2010 and those that were still in default.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1888930-la-corte-de-nueva-york-confentina |title=La Corte de Nueva York confirmó la orden de Thomas Griesa para que la Argentina salga del default |trans-title=The Court of New York confirmed the order of Thomas Griesa for Argentina to leave the default|language=Spanish|author=Rafael Mathus Ruiz|work=La Nacion|accessdate=April 13, 2016}}</ref> The payment will be done with a bond sale.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/fastft/2016/04/13/us-court-ruling-allows-argentina-bond-sale-to-proceed/|title=US court ruling allows Argentina bond sale to proceed|date=April 13, 2016|publisher= Financial Times|accessdate=April 13, 2016}}</ref> This appeared to the media to be the end of the Argentine default, which had started in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-13/argentina-wins-court-ruling-letting-bond-sale-proceed|title= Argentina Wins Court Ruling Letting Bond Sale Proceed|author= Bob Van Voris|date=April 13, 2016|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=April 13, 2016}}</ref>
However, nearly US$1 billion in defaulted bonds remained unpaid, which resulted in continuing though less publicised litigation. Argentina finally reported in November 2016 that it had reached agreements to pay US$475 million to settle the outstanding defaulted debt.<ref name="lanacion.com.ar"/> In January 2017, ''[[The Economist]]'' reported that the [[MSCI]] index would be considering re-accepting Argentina’s shares over 2017, and on January 5, [[JPMorgan Chase]] also said it would admit Argentina into its benchmark indices early in the year.<ref name="Economist_Bonds_2017">{{Citation | title =Argentina is admitted to a widely tracked bond index | newspaper = [[The Economist]] | date =January 14, 2017 | url =https://www.economist.com/news/finance-and-economics/21714370-fifteen-years-after-spectacular-default-argentine-regains-respectability?fsrc=scn/tw/te/bl/ed/argentinaisadmittedtoawidelytrackedbondindex | access-date =January 15, 2017 }}</ref> On March 6, 2017, ''[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]]'' reported that [[Moody's|Moody’s Investors Services]] had “raised its outlook on Argentina’s credit rating to positive from stable.”<ref>{{Citation | last =DeFotis | first = Dimitra | title =Argentina Debt Outlook Improving, Moody’s Says | newspaper = [[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]] | date =March 6, 2017 | url = http://blogs.barrons.com/emergingmarketsdaily/2017/03/06/argentina-debt-outlook-improving-moodys-says/ | access-date =April 2, 2017}}</ref>
